newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Investors seen fine-tuning Russian share holdings.
newsitem.headline: Investors seen fine-tuning Russian share holdings.

text.p: Shares of Russian second-tier oil companies firmed and preferred stocks eased on low volumes on Thursday as investors and dealers shuffled their portfolios, dealers said.
"People are fine-tuning their second-tiers," said ING Barings chief equities trader Peter Kizenko.
The Russian Trading System index eased less than one percent to 190.16 on $14.7 million market turnover.
Purneftegaz firmed to $2.40 from $2.30 on Wednesday while Tomskneft preferred eased to $3.63 from $3.75. Krasnoyarskenergo fell to $0.210 from $0.265 on December 2.
Dealers saw little sharp change due in the market, although traders were divided whether speculators anticipating investor interest in the New Year might spark an end-of-year rally.

UES, the dollar volume leader of the day, rallied after a morning dip, continuing a week-long move upward to close at $0.0845 after a dip to $0.0830 during the day and $0.0843 at Wednesday's close. It's low was near $0.0810 on November 28.
"I think we'll see nine," said one trader at a Western firm who said some of the buying in the market could be intended to move the price.
A number of market sources said UES was pushed up on Wednesday and Thursday by rumours that a single Western buyer had bid for an 8.5 percent stake to be auctioned at month end.

Two sources said utility Mosenergo had not broken out of a month-long tight trading range, despite positive company news, because one or a number of institutional investors were taking profit on substantial stakes near the $1.00 level.
Mosenergo firmed to $0.986 from $0.981. It reported nine month profits earlier in the week and on Thursday announced it would issue Russia's first corporate Eurobond in the first quarter of 1997.
"Mosenergo is going to be underperforming for several weeks to come," said a trader at a Western firm who added that Rostelekom, which eased to $2.36 from $2.40 was doing well.
"It has had about six million shares dumped on the market," since news that a 38 percent stake would be turned over to regional telecoms holding company Svyazinvest, he said.
